questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following gross motor milestone would you expect to see in a 3-year-old child?
questions.explanation: A three-year-old should normally be able to walk upstairs with alternate feet.

questions.question:
Question 2: You notice a child pulling to the standing position and then shuffling around by holding onto 
furniture. At what age is this milestone typically attained?
questions.explanation:
Cruising is an activity in which a child pulls to the standing position and then shuffles around 
holding onto a piece of furniture. Cruising is attained by 10-11 months.

questions.question:
Question 3: In the pediatric wards, you notice a baby, totally occupied with his little game and a mother 
trying hard to spoonfeed him. He is busy stacking toy cubes on top of each other and starts 
gleefully clapping once he makes a tower of 6. What is the likely age that this milestone 
corresponds to?
questions.explanation: A child can usually make a tower of 6 blocks by 24 months. A child makes a tower of: • 2 blocks by 15 months • 3 blocks by 18 months • 6 blocks by 2 years • 9 blocks by 3 years

questions.question:
Question 4: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained? 68 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 
months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed 
thumb and the tip of the index finger. Developmental progression of the grasp: • At 6 months, the infant reaches and holds a larger object in a crude manner using the ulnar 
aspect of his hand (Ulnar palmar grasp). At 8-9 months, the object is grasped by the radial side of 
the palm (radial palmar grasp). • At 9 months, the immature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the adducted 
thumb and the extended index finger. • At 12 months, the mature pincer grasp develops. The object is secured between the opposed 
thumb and the tip of the index finger. 75 
Sold by @itachibot Immature pincer grasp (9 months) PM/\RR0W Mature pincer grasp (12 months) ›MARROW

questions.question:
Question 5: A final-year medical student is examining a baby in the ward. As the infant is pulled to sit, he 
notices a head lag. By what age should this infant ideally start to hold his head steady without 
any bobbing motion?
questions.explanation:
An infant can hold his head steady when pulled to sit, without head bobbing, by the age of 4 
months. Regarding head steadiness: • Up till 2 months of age, there is a significant head lag when the infant is pulled to sit. 76 
Sold by @itachibot • At 3 months, head lag is partially compensated but still present; the infant attains early head 
control with bobbing motion and sits with back rounded. • At 4 months, there is no head lag when pulled to sit and the infant sits with full truncal support.

questions.question:
Question 6: Your sister tells you that your nephew has now started using his crayons. He easily copies 
circles, but still has trouble with squares. Other than a minor ASD noted incidentally at birth, 
he is a perfectly healthy child. Which of the following would you expect him to be able to do 
at this stage?
questions.explanation:
Normally, a child is able to copy a circle at 3 years and a square at 4 years. This child is a 
3-year-old, and he should be able to know his name and gender. • A child is able to tell a story at 4 years. • Asks meaning of words at 5 years. • A child can skip at 5 years.

questions.question: Question 7: Match the following milestones with corresponding age.
questions.explanation: Handedness is established during the 3rd year (24 to 36 months). Taste perception is present since birth. Monosyllabic babble is seen at 6 months. Response to faces and voices with a smile is seen at 1.5 months. The child creeps upstairs by 15 months.

questions.question:
Question 8: You are taking a detailed history from the parents of a child with a suspected autism 
spectrum disorder. Parents are worried that their child does not smile or maintain eye contact 
and is not interested in toys. At what ages should a typical child exhibit "social smile" and 
"stranger anxiety"?
questions.explanation:
Social smile is typically seen at 2 months and stranger anxiety at 6 months. 77 
Sold by @itachibot Social smile: At 1 month of age, a child smiles involuntarily. At 2 months of age social smile 
develops; that is, the child smiles voluntarily and reciprocally, in response to someone else’s smile. Stranger anxiety: Before 6 months, the child is sociable and friendly even with strangers. At 6 
months, there is an onset of stranger anxiety; infants look back and forth between an approaching 
stranger and parent and may cling or cry anxiously.

questions.question:
Question 9: A pediatrician is evaluating a toddler for mental retardation. She hands a bright red ball to 
the baby and lets him play with it. She then takes the ball and hides it under a blanket in 
front of him. The child confusedly stares at the blanket and cries instead of searching for it. 
What is being tested here?
questions.explanation:
Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called object permanence. This 
is due to an ability to form a mental representation of the object. It is attained at the age of 8–9 
months. Option A: Separation anxiety begins at about 9 months of age. Children wake up crying from their 
naps as they realize that their parents are not in the same room as them. This is different from 
stranger anxiety displayed by the child at the age of 6-7 months, wherein they react to 
approaching strangers by crying or clinging to their parent. Option B: A transitional object is an object, such as a blanket or a stuffed toy, that is used by many 
children as a symbol of the absent parent. It is seen at around 18 months. Option C: Symbolic transformations in play: • At 12 months - make-believe (symbolic) play centres on the child’s own body, e.g., the child 
pretends to drink from an empty cup. • At 18 month - symbolic transformations in play are not limited to the child's body, e.g., a doll 
can be fed from a plate.

questions.question:
Question 10: 70 
Sold by @itachibot Parents of 9-month-old infant, with a history of preterm delivery and prolonged NICU stay, 
are concerned that child is lagging behind in his milestones. You would suspect a 
developmental delay in this child if his developmental quotient (DQ) is below  
 %?
questions.explanation:
A developmental delay should be suspected if the development quotient (DQ) is below 70%. It is calculated as: DQ = Developmental age x 100Chronological age From the highest milestones achieved by the child, the developmental age in a particular domain 
is calculated. The chronological age is the actual age in term babies. However, in preterm infants, 
a corrected age rather than postnatal age is used till two years of age. This is used to account for 
the small gap in neurological development that premature children have yet to catch up. For 
example, a child born at 32 weeks gestation (gestational age) seen at 12 weeks of age (postnatal 
age), should be considered as a 4-week-old (corrected age) child. If there is a delay (DQ<70%) in more than 2 domains, then global developmental delay (GDD) is 
suspected.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following milestones is expected to be seen in a child at 5 years of age?

options.c: Riding a tricycle and making a tower of 9 blocks
options.d: Establishment of handedness and parallel play

questions.explanation:
78 
Sold by @itachibot Developmental milestones at the age of 5 years include: • Motor - skips • Adaptive - Draws a triangle • Language - Asks meaning of words • Social - Dresses and undresses Undressing is easier and hence learned before dressing. • 2 years - Helps to undress • 3 years - Helps in dressing (if helped with buttons) • 5 years - Dress and undress fully (without any help)

questions.question:
Question 12: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear, that he reaches out 
to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved?
questions.explanation:
The earliest age of appearance of bidextrous reach is 4 months. Fine motor reflexes begin to appear only after the palmar grasp reflex disappears at 3-4 
months. The development of unidextrous reach occurs by 6 months of age.

questions.question:
Question 14: A child was able to count 4 pennies but was unable to name 4 colors. The probable age of the 
child is  
.
questions.explanation:
A 4-year-old child can count 4 pennies but cannot name 4 colours. A child can name 4 colours at 5 
years of age. Note: An easy way to remember this: • No. of objects counted = age • No. of colours identified = age - 1

questions.question:
Question 15: A term, 4-month-old infant, is developing normally. By what age do you expect her to walk 
without support and use polysyllabic jargon?
questions.explanation:
A 15-month-old child can walk without support and use polysyllabic jargon. Walking: A child begins to cruise at 10 months, walk with support at 12 months, and walk without 
support at 15 months. Jargon is seen around 15 months of age. It is a pre-linguistic vocalization in which the child 
babbles using strings of word-like sounds and produces words that do not make much sense to 
others.

questions.question:
Question 16: One of the kids has scribbled all over a newly painted wall inside an Anganwadi. You notice 
there are some triangles and squares as well, in this "drawing". This child must be older than
questions.explanation: The milestones at 5 years of age are: • Motor - skips • Adaptive - draws triangle • Language - asks meaning of words, names 4 colors • Social - dresses and undresses

questions.question:
Question 17: The absence of which of the following milestones in a 3-year-old child is called as 
developmental delay?
questions.explanation:
Feeding by spoon is a social milestone that typically appears by 18 months. If this is absent, then 
the child should be termed as having a developmental delay. Hopping on one leg, drawing a 
square, and passing a ball to someone appear by 48 months of age. Red flag signs in developmental screening and surveillance are indicators that suggest a serious 
disorder in a child's development, requiring referral to a pediatrician. These are given below: Positive indicators: Presence of any of the following • Loss of developmental skills at any age • Concerns about vision or confirmed visual impairment 80 
Sold by @itachibot • Hearing loss at any age • Persistently low muscle tone • Lack of speech by 18 months without other means of communication • Asymmetry of movements or features suggestive of cerebral palsy • Persistent toe walking • Complex disabilities • Unusual head circumference compared to norms • Clinician uncertainty about the developmental disorder. Negative Indicators: • Inability to sit unsupported by 12 months • Inability to walk by 18 months in boys or 2 years in girls. • Inability to walk normally • Inability to run by 2.5 years • Inability to hold objects in hand by 5 months or reach for them by 6 months. • Inability to point at objects to share interest by 2 years

questions.question:
Question 18: After assessing a young child treated for unilateral retinoblastoma, you note significant delays 
in the cognitive and fine motor domains. The baby can stand without support and creep well. 
Normally, the highest fine motor skill a baby of this age is expected to have is
questions.explanation:
A baby that stands without support is most likely to be 12 months. The highest fine motor skill she 
is expected to have is mature pincer grasp (12 months). Bidextrous reach is seen at 4 months and unidextrous reach at 6 months. Immature pincer grasp 
is seen at 9 months. Child begins to scribble after 15 months. Fine motor development is critically linked with hand-eye coordination. Children who have 
disease-related loss of vision in early infancy develop difficulties in visuomotor integration and 
lags behind in fine motor milestones.

questions.question:
Question 19: You are a pediatrics resident handling the well-child clinic for the week and you are teaching 
undergraduates how to do a simple developmental assessment. A preterm baby born at 32 
weeks, is brought in for a follow-up visit at 6 months. What is the age you would ask the 
students to assume when undertaking developmental assessment in this child?
questions.explanation:
The corrected age (in weeks) to be assumed while undertaking developmental assessment is 16 
weeks. Corrected age (in weeks) = (Gestational age + postnatal age) - 40 weeks In this case, since the baby is born 8 weeks preterm, the 8 weeks of intrauterine growth and 
development she missed, is accounted for post-natally. Thus, for assessing the correct 
developmental age, 8 weeks has to be subtracted from the chronological age. In babies born preterm, corrected age is used for their developmental assessment until 2 years of 
age. 81 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: All of the following statements are true regarding principles of development except?

options.a: It is dependent on the functional maturation of the nervous system
options.b: Specific responses replace mass activity as the child matures
options.d: In the extremities, development occurs distal to proximal

questions.explanation:
In the extremities, development occurs proximal to distal. Rules of development: • It is a continuous process • It depends on the functional maturation of the nervous system • The sequence of attainment of milestones is the same in all children • It progresses in a cephalocaudal direction and proximal to distal. • Certain primitive reflexes have to be lost before relevant milestones are attained • The initial disorganized mass activity is gradually replaced by specific actions. Question 21: 73 
Sold by @itachibot A young infant is brought to you with a suspected developmental delay. The child is intently 
looking at his own hands. You would consider referring this child to a specialist if this 
milestone persists after  
.

options.c: A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
options.d: A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.explanation:
Between 12 and 20 weeks, the child observes his own hands very intently. This milestone is called 
hand regard and it should disappear by 20 weeks. Its persistence after 20 weeks is considered 
abnormal. In a blind child, however, it may persist beyond 20 weeks normally and is called apparent hand 
regard. 82 
Sold by @itachibot Facets of Growth and Development
